customer_reviews.title: Fantastic text for beginners
customer_reviews.text: I am new to the web design world. I chose this text to learn HTML, CSS, and JavaScript for myself so that I could teach it to my students. I am so thrilled with everything about this textbook. Printing, layout, content, exercises, etc. The author has done an excellent job at making a complex subject simple to understand. I would highly recommend this text to other teachers. Many of the standard textbooks out there are incredibly expensive and boring. This text makes learning easy and fun.
customer_reviews.author: Joshua D. Washburn

customer_reviews.title: Great introduction for web novices
customer_reviews.text: True to its title, this comprehensive book takes web novices from the bare basics to a working knowledge of designing websites. Jennifer Robbins provides clear and comprehensive instructions that even one with no web experience can understand. I highly recommend this book.
customer_reviews.author: Skylark

customer_reviews.title: Good book!
customer_reviews.text: Overall this is a well-written book, and the free online companion resources are very helpful. The only reason I didn't give it five stars is that many of the details a person needs to design a web page are buried in the flowing narrative. The author states that reading the book is like sitting in her class, and I have no doubt that she puts on a great class. However, when class is over and you're sitting at home looking for those three or four key tags you need, a chapter glossary or searchable list would be nice. This is especially true in the CSS section. Again, it is a very good and readable book for learning the basics.
customer_reviews.author: Daniel Dellar

customer_reviews.title: Great CSS3 overview
customer_reviews.text: Very good intro book to CSS with an overview of HTML5. There is also a section on graphics which wasn't relevant for me, but seemed pretty good also. I read the book on Kindle for MAC which I found imperfect. It was hard to get a font size I liked and the page turning wasn't natural. Figures / examples often were on 'the next page' highlighting the next/previous page challenge. I also think I would refer back to it more if it were hard copy. I would recommend it for content.
customer_reviews.author: Kenneth Carr

customer_reviews.title: hand-coded website that looks way better and gives me total control
customer_reviews.text: I was new to HTML and CSS, but this book helped me take my website from the very frustrating and buggy Microsoft Expression, to a clean, hand-coded website that looks way better and gives me total control. There is still lots of information packed in this book that I need to review. I have not yet read any other books on web design, but I can say I was very happy with this one. I wouldn't recommend it so much for learning JavaScript, as it seems the author of this section just gives a brief and somewhat confusing overview, at least for me. But for HTML and CSS this book was great!
customer_reviews.author: Jason

customer_reviews.title: Easy  path to learn.
customer_reviews.text: A good introductory work into web development. A comprehensive coverage of the field, full of helpful links to further reading and a lot of experienced advices, also encouraging to follow the latest standard and browser-specific specifications as well as workarounds for browsers not up-to-date to the most recent recommendations. I've read a lot of introductory books on this topic even from ones better rated than this, as I always felt lacking the proper foundations to pursue more advanced teachings for proficiency and finally this one provides me with the coveted background to move forward. Recommended as one of the few best choices, to everyone starting to learn the craft.
customer_reviews.author: Osvaldo Dias dos Santos

customer_reviews.title: Not quite the order I would have organized the chapters, but very easy to use.
customer_reviews.text: In my opinion, chapter 16, the chapter where they finally introduce CSS should have been further up the list of chapters instead of having you do all the formatting of the web pages on the same page of code as the HTML. This is a minor problem though, and really only bothered me because I have done a good bit of design using WYSIWYG editors and knew that in page CSS is not where it should go unless you need to override the main CSS file. I will definitely agree with many of the other reviews as this is the go to book to get started in web design.
customer_reviews.author: Zack Thompson

customer_reviews.title: good beginner reference book
customer_reviews.text: Not quite the content I expected. The writing style makes it an easy read. It's a good reference book for html tags and has filled in some elementary knowledge gaps. However, examples given in the book seem more oriented towards formatting text on a web page and I'm looking for deeper explanations for how to exchange data between a web page and a database. I would have liked to have seen more page display results for the sample html presented. It would be a good starter book for someone who doesn't know html at all. For myself, I need something that goes a little deeper.
customer_reviews.author: lmm2005

customer_reviews.title: Web Design Concepts for the Novice
customer_reviews.text: The aim of this book is to give an individual that has little or no background in web applications or technologies a basic understanding of how the web and web pages work. It is written in a colloquial style in an attempt to disarm and relax the reader -which can be a challenge with any type of technical book. The author does a decent job of breaking concepts that can quickly spiral into the unintelligible due to the subject matter. At the end of every chapter, there are summaries and quizzes to reinforce the material covered. This book is a good starting point for HTML, CSS and JavaScript exposure.
customer_reviews.author: Pnut Butta

customer_reviews.title: Don't buy the 4th edition. It was published in 2012. Get the 5th edition.
customer_reviews.text: I'm really kind of upset that I bought the 4th edition without being able to find the 5th (published in 2018) until after my order was delivered. HTML, CSS and graphics change so rapidly in today's web environment. A seven year old book is like an 1820 encyclopedia. Kind of quaint but of very little practical use.
customer_reviews.author: Martin Fields

customer_reviews.title: Very well written and organized book
customer_reviews.text: I highly recommend this book to anyone wanting detailed training of web front-end design. It is easy to comprehend, has great examples, has exercises, and has online support with sample coding for the training exercises. It is well organized and easy to follow. Has a comprehensive index and chapters have summary tables at the end for easy reference. I have only a little spare time here and there to learn web page design, and the books organization and style make it easy to pick up where I left off, sometimes days or weeks later. I highly recommend it.
customer_reviews.author: Train man

customer_reviews.title: Great for students
customer_reviews.text: I have used this as my textbook for my Web Design and Development class for two semesters now. The students really like it - it includes the detail they need, and mentions extras or advanced stuff with links if they want to pursue them. It is well structured, too - first dealing with HTML, and then turning the corner to CSS, which lines up perfectly with one of my mantras - "make it work, then make it pretty."

customer_reviews.title: and I found the material easy to engage with

(Note: the JavaScript chapters are just there to give you a sense of what the language is all about--this book makes no pretense at being a solid introduction to the language.) There are lots of practical examples here, and I found the material easy to engage with. As an aside, Mark Myers has also written a book about HTML and CSS that deals with this subject more programmatically. I found reading his book after this one really helped drive home the key information, so feel free to give this a try if you feel inclined.
